Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk glibc
exit 0

isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk glibc
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: glibc bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description:
Updated glibc packages that fix several bugs are now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7. The glibc packages provide the standard C libraries (libc), POSIX thread libraries (libpthread), standard math libraries (libm), and the Name Server Caching Daemon (nscd) used by multiple programs on the system. Without these libraries, the Linux system cannot function correctly.
This update fixes the following bugs:
* Previously, Name Service Switch (NSS) module using hash-indexed files (nss_db) initialized itself incorrectly. Consequently, when nss_db module was enabled and any of the get*ent functions, such as getservent(), was called before a corresponding set*ent call, the application that called get*ent terminated unexpectedly. With this update, nss_db initialization sequence is fixed. As a result, calling get*ent functions without first calling set*ent works as expected, and the application no longer crashes. (BZ#1388635)
* The nss_db module failed to request larger result buffers when parsing group entries. As a consequence, group entries with a size in a specific range were skipped. With this update, nss_db detects when a group list does not fit into the result buffer and requests a larger buffer. As a result, group entries in the affected size range are processed correctly. (BZ#1388637)
* Previously, installing an Identity Management (IdM) server or client did not add the "sss" option to the "initgroups" lookup entry in the /etc/nsswitch.conf file. As a consequence, looking up secondary groups for users managed by the System Security Services Daemon (SSSD) did not work as expected. With the update, looking up secondary groups works correctly. (BZ#1388638)
* Previously, the nss_db module did not properly handle a protocol mismatch during lookups in the service database. As a consequence, lookups in the service database could enter an infinite loop. Now, nss_db deals with protocol mismatches and proceeds with the next entry. As a result, service entries are found as expected without entering an infinite loop. (BZ#1388639)
Users of glibc are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs.
Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
